I had one cine, a clue so slight that it had been overlooked by the Russian police, but one which no really first-class detective would have passed unnoticed. On the dead mans throat were the black marks of the fingers which had strangled him. The thumb of the right hand had been pressed violently into the skin of the neck, so as to produce a deep abrasion. I at once took a careful cast of this thumb-mark with the finest wax, thus reproducing every line exactly. I know that the impression of no two thumbs in the world are alike. It is the prison-mask in China, re member, and there serves the same purpose as the Rogues Gallery in America to identify a criminal. One other clue I had to guide me. A plain twisted ring, worn by the murderer,had left its mark distinctly on the flesh. I caused the impres sion of the hand, ring and all, to be photographed. Furnished only with these slight clues, I now set out to find the mur derer of Paul Pelaufski. Instinct toU me, I suppose, to look for him in the best society of the capital. I soon discovered this man to be a red-hot Nihilist. The Baroness for the time was absolutely infatuated with him. During all this time you may sup pose that 1 kept a sharp lookout for the twisted ring. I did nothing of the kind. document.text: W ork of Private Detectives. Doutless not one person in a thou sand has a correct idea of the character or significance of this most singular outgrowth, of ultra-civilized conditions. The detective connected with the police department is complimented by the press whenever he captures a gang of thieves or discovers an incendiary, but with the private detective the case is different. Long before he embarks in the business he must above all things, learn he derj himself the sweets of praise and the joys oi fame. He must lay aside personal vanity, for his suc cess lies not in forcing himself to the front, but remaining as much as pos sible in the background. He need nave no fear that customers will forget him, for, like a six-shooter, a private detec tive is one of the things that, when needed, is required instanterif not sooner. A modest sign, which the average well-behaved and well-condi- j tioned person might pass every day for j years without noticing, but which looms  up as big as a barn to the jealous wife 1 who wants her husband shadowed, is all  the advertising he needs. He need not be alarmed for fear his clients will not find his room, and take a suite of large and conspicuous apartments in the front of the building he occupies, for when the man who is being bled and blackmailed starts out to hunt up a pri vate detective he will find him if he has to get out a search warrant.

Sev eral shots were fired at Kahney with fatal effect. After the shooting the burglars fled from the house. As soon as the murder of Kahney was reported to the police department Superintendent OMeara put the entire force of detectives to work on the case. Several of the offi cers came upon the three burglars on Fulton street, and immediately the fu gitives opened fire. The officers prompt ly returned the fire, and in the fusilade that followed  Paddy Fitzgerald, one of Pittsburgs oldest and best known de tectives, was almost instantly killed and two other officers are reported wounded.

document.text: One of the ironies of recent civilian evacuation tests, involving Wash ington and other U. S. defense centers, i 3 the fact that the American people havent been given adequate information to know what a real attack would mean. For one thing, the destructiveness of the bombs now being made in this country and Russia already make the recently-conducted evacuation drills obsolete. The recent drills were based on the possibility of atomic- bomb attacks. Yet the evacuations practiced would not have afforded protection against an attack with more destructive weapons now being made and available. The fall-out of radio-active ash would have caused casualties almost beyond estimation had the recent evacuation drills been the real thing. There has been a dangerous amount of foot-dragging in giving the American people the facts about the new developments in the hydrogen- bomb field. New bombs are so powerful there is practically no defense against them. In addition, there has been a scandalous delay in the production and distribution of detectors which citizens should have in ample numbers to day they should have had them a year or two ago. Without the de tectors it is impossible for the average citizen to know whether he has been contaminated with radio-active ash or fall-out, or not. Yet it was pointed out in Washington that civilian defense officials had only four radio-active measuring counters, or detectors, in that city the national capital when the recent drill took place. Four when a hundred thousand would have been needed! This is necessary because if a person finds he has been subjected to radio-active fall-out he must act immediately, if he is to save his life. And radio activity cannot be detected by the eye, or by feel, until it is too late! The Administration should immediately okay a simple geiger count er, or detector, for manufacture. They should become a part of the equipment of every fire station, police department, and civilian defense organization in the country. The United States is woefully unprepared in the field of civilian de fense  so unprepared it staggers the imagination to think what would happen if this country actually sustained such an attack. The people need the awful facts, and they need a plentiful supply of portable detectors, and that responsibility rests with the Administration.
